catalyst.context: Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C 3 N 4 ) is paying attention lately owing to its interesting characteristics and substantial application in improving environmental and energy concerns.Nevertheless, the photocatalytic activity of g-C 3 N 4 is constrained by the inertness of the surface and particle aggregation during photocatalytic activity.Herein, we report the preparation of g-C 3 N 4 with honeycomb-like morphology (HC-C 3 N 4 ) via thermal condensation of prepared SiO 2 templates and dicyandiamide.The etching out of the SiO 2 templates by NH 4 HF 2 created hollow or macropores in the C 3 N 4 matrix resulting in its structural changes.Similar, to the bulk C 3 N 4 , the HC-C 3 N 4 exhibited higher photocatalytic CO 2 reduction in hydrocarbons.This improved photocatalytic achievement is associated with higher specific surface area, excellent visible light absorption capability, higher electron donor density, easy mass diffusion of materials for surface reaction, and effective segregation of photogenerated charge carriers.Furthermore, the HC-C 3 N 4 honeycomb structure was deposited with Ni(OH) 2 clusters which showed remarkable CO 2 reduction activity of 1.48 molh -1 g -1 of CH 4 and 0.73 molh -1 g -1 of CH 3 OH generation which is 3.5 and 4.3 times higher CO 2 reduction activity compared with bulk C 3 N 4 clustered with Ni(OH) 2 particles.This comprehensive study demonstrated that HC-C 3 N 4 nanostructured polymeric semiconductor is envisaged to have great potential in the application of a variety of fields such as photocatalysis, sensor technology, and nanotechnology.

catalyst.context: Honeycomb-like graphitic carbon nitride (HC-C 3 N 4 ) was fabricated through thermal compression of an as-prepared SiO 2 template and dicyandiamide.The NH 4 HF 2 etching out of the SiO 2 template results in the creation of hollows or macropores in the C 3 N 4 matrix leading to the superior specific surface area.The HC-C 3 N 4 shows only structural changes but not in chemical composition correlated to the bulk C 3 N 4 .Compared with the bulk C 3 N 4 , the HC-C 3 N 4 nanostructure demonstrated a higher photocatalytic CO 2 reduction rate of hydrocarbon formation.The higher photocatalytic activity showed by HC-C 3 N 4 could be credited to the void nature of the structure, higher surface area, excellent visible light absorption ability, higher electron donor density, mass diffusion of materials for surface redox reaction, and effective segregation of photogenerated charge carriers due to the decrease in its wall thickness.Further, to confirm the enhanced photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activity, Ni(OH) 2 nanoparticles were grown over the honeycomb g-C 3 N 4 structure to provide electron sink and to encourage charge dissolution efficiency.The asprepared Ni(OH) 2 decorated honeycomb g-C 3 N 4 hybrids displayed an excellent visible light photocatalytic CO 2 reduction to solar fuels with 1.48 molh -1 g -1 of CH 4 and 0.73 molh -1 g -1 of CH 3 OH generation, respectively.This study showed that the morphology tuning of C 3 N 4 can be an excellent strategy of producing low-cost and sustainable photocatalyst for mitigating increase CO 2 levels in the environment into clean solar fuels. co-catalyst.context: The X-ray diffraction patterns of HC-C 3 N 4 and bulk C 3 N 4 samples are revealed in Fig. 1.Two typical characteristic diffractions at 2 13.0and27.1can be observed in the XRD patterns in both samples.The weak peak at 13.1is due to the in-plane architectural packing of continuous heptazine or striazine units that can be recorded to the (100) plane.The strong peak at 27.1signifies the interlayer loading of aromatic segments indexed to the (002) plane (JCPDS 087-1526).These two essential diffraction peaks illustrate that the asprepared samples are g-C 3 N 4 and very well matched with the earlier reports (Li et al. 2015d;Yang et al. 2015;Zhang et al. 2014).The reduction in (002) peak intensity of the HC-C 3 N 4 sample can be attributed to poor crystallization and the creation of large pores or hollow interior within the structure, which reduced the length of interlayer periodicity or atomic arrangements (Zhang et al. 2013;Talapaneni et al. 2012).The exterior arrangement of the HC-C 3 N 4 sample was further investigated by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM).The FESEM images show honeycomb morphology (Fig. 2a-d). The porous C 3 N 4 structure with a hollow interior replicates the precise nature of the SiO 2 templates after etching out as shown in Fig. 2a-d.The diameter of the interior hollows ranges ca.50-80 nm with irregular intervals in the C 3 N 4 framework on the surface of the sample.The porosity of the HC-C 3 N 4 texture framework is further supported by the TEM analysis Fig. 2e-f.The TEM characterization further shows the existence of interior hollow or pores introduced alongside with the considerable number of surface defects. The EDX elemental mapping images (Fig. 3) show a uniform allocation of both carbon (C) and nitrogen (N) as the only components within the HC-C 3 N 4 sample, without any other elements such as silica or oxygen.The elemental study shows that the HC-C 3 N 4 has a C/N molar ratio of 0.72, while the bulk C 3 N 4 shows 0.70.The respective stoichiometric C: N ratio is C 3.2 :N 4.4 and C 2.9 :N 4.1 for HC-C 3 N 4 and bulk C 3 N 4 , respectively.These results are nearby to the hypothetical value of 0.75 for ideal g-C 3 N 4 , suggesting some incomplete condensation which is normally examined in the preparation of g-C 3 N 4 (Kailasam et al. 2011;Li et al. 2012). The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the HC-C 3 N 4 sample was conducted to determine the thermal stability, decomposition behavior, and final carbon nitride content (i.e., purity).The HC-C 3 N 4 and bulk C 3 N 4 samples were warmed from ambient temperature to 900 C at a heating rate of 10 C min -1 under air, and the subsequent outcome is shown in Fig. 4. A complete weight loss takes place in both samples beyond 700 C after experiencing two stages of significant weight.The first stage occurred at 400 C with 6.7 and 5.5 wt losses for HC-C 3 N 4 and bulk C 3 N 4 , respectively, was caused by thermal removal of hydroxyl groups or bound water particles and other absorbed unstable contaminations on the facade of the samples.The second stage witnessed rapid and significant weight loss from 450 to 620 C corresponding to 91.7 wt loss for the HC-C 3 N 4 .The bulk-C 3 N 4 completely decomposes at 670 C, which corresponds to 94.1 wt.This reaction is generated from the decomposition of C-N bondrelated frameworks in the carbon nitride polymer and their sublimation into g-C 3 N 4 gaseous products.It can be observed from the TG curves that the decomposition behavior of the HC-C 3 N 4 occurred at a lower temperature relative to the bulk C 3 N 4 .This is due to the formation of hollows or pores within the C 3 N 4 matrix, which increases the mesoporosity and surface area of the HC-C 3 N 4 sample.These results make the HC-C 3 N 4 sample less heavy and lead to easily decomposed at lower temperatures. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) test was further conducted to disclose the microstructure of the HC-C 3 N 4 asprepared sample.There are similarities in the spectra characteristics of both HC-C 3 N 4 and bulk C 3 N 4 as-prepared samples as shown in Fig. 5.This signifies the excellent maintenance of both the heptazine (or s-triazine) band and trigonal C-N(-C)-C/bridging C-NH-C components in the samples.The sharp peak at around 811 cm -1 fits into the breathing mode of the heptazine or s-triazine band.The firm peaks at 1215-1640 cm -1 are ascribed to the elongation or bending vibration of the aromatic carbon and nitrogen heterocycles (i.e., C-N and/or CN bonds).Besides, the extensive characteristic band in a range of 3105-3700 cm -1 is attributed to the stretching vibrations of residual N-H bonds in the primary and secondary amines (NH or -NH 2 ) groups and adsorbed water molecules (Zheng et al. 2014;Kang et al. 2015).All these observations suggest that the HC-C 3 N 4 prepared is similar to the reference bulk C 3 N 4 with some NH or -NH 2 groups in the samples, an indication of incomplete condensation.It further shows that all the SiO 2 templates were etched out and the strong etching reagent (NH 4 HF 2 ) does not have any effect on the robust structure of the HC-C 3 N 4 synthesized. Figure 6 shows the N 2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and the corresponding pore size allocation curves of the asprepared samples.The entire samples exhibited type IV isotherms, suggesting the existence of mesopores inside the samples (Sing 1985).The profile of the hysteresis loops is of type H3, signifying the presence of slit-like mesopores owing to the accumulation of plate-like grains.Furthermore, it can be seen that the isotherms exhibited a high relative pressure range (approaching 1.0), signifying the arrangement of large mesopores and macropores.The pore size allocation curves ranged from 2 to 120 nm (inset in Fig. 6) further confirmed the mesoporosity of the samples.The HC-C 3 N 4 sample exhibited only the existence of large mesopores at a peak pore size of 42 nm and macropores at 75 nm.This was due to the successful creation of large interior hollows or cylindrical channels within the C 3 N 4 matrix of HC-C 3 N 4 samples, after the exclusion of the silica templates which is evidenced by the FESEM and TEM images.However, small mesopores (3.5-4.5 nm), huge mesopores, and macropores (42-75 nm) can be examined in the bulk sample.The BET values for the as-prepared samples are shown in Table 1.It can be seen that the HC-C 3 N 4 sample has a significantly higher surface area and pore volume (2.5 times higher) than the bulk C 3 N 4 .This can be ascribed to the creation of a huge amount of macropores within the C 3 N 4 matrix.This results would lead to effective surface absorption of reactants and faster photogenerated carrier separation and thus enhancement in photocatalytic activity.The reduction in the BET values in the HC-C 3 N 4 /Ni(OH) 2 sample can be attributed to the evidence of the Ni(OH) 2 cocatalyst which may be ingrained in the C 3 N 4 pores and thus decreasing the BET surface area and pore volume. The chemical distribution and elemental status of HC-C 3 N 4 and bulk C 3 N 4 were distinguished by XPS analysis, and the outcome is illustrated in Fig. 7a.The survey spectra of both samples show only C, N, and O elements.There was no signal detection of silicon species which confirms the successful removal of the SiO 2 templates used in the preparation of the HC-C 3 N 4 .However, the presence of the O1s peak could be attributed to exterior preoccupied water molecules as definite by the FT-IR results (Fig. 5). Figure 7b shows that C1s peak deconvoluted into three peaks.The peak at 286.4 and 288.0 eV binding energies are attributed to sp 2 C-C bonds and sp 2 -hybridized carbon in nitrogen-incorporated aromatic ring (N-CN), respectively.However, the peak at binding energy (284.exterior extrinsic carbon, derived from the sample and the XPS instrument itself (Yang et al. 2015;Zheng et al. 2014).The high-resolution XPS spectra of N 1s were indexed into four peaks at binding energies 398.4,399.0, 400.3, and 404.2 eV, respectively, as shown in Fig. 7c.The highest peak at 398.4 eV binding energies is ascribed to sp 2 -hybridized aromatic nitrogen bonding in the triazine rings with two carbon atoms (C-NC).The peak at 400.3 eV correlates to the tertiary nitrogen N-(C)3 groups.Both peaks jointly with sp 2hybridized carbon (N-CN, at 288.0 eV) conform to heptazine heterocyclic ring units which are the essential building substructure for g-C 3 N 4 .The weak peak at 400.3 eV can be allocated to N-H bonds which indicate the presence of amino functional groups due to the deficient concentration of poly (tri-s-triazine) structures (Gu et al. 2015;Qin et al. 2015).The weakest peak at binding energy (404.2eV) can be credited to -excitations or positive charge localization in the heterocycles (Li et al. 2015a, b, c, d;Yu et al. 2014a, b). light source.context: Preparation of the solid silica (SiO 2 ) template The SiO 2 templates were produced according to the previously published Stober method with minor modification (Qin et al. 2014).In detail, 12 mL of tetraethoxysilane (TEOS) was quickly put into a blend of ethanol (148 mL), deionized water (20 mL), and aqueous ammonium solution (25-28, 6.30 mL).The blended solution was then mixed for 1 h under room temperature, ensuring the production of a white silica suspension.The resultant silica particles were detached from the solution and washed several times with ethanol and water.The as-produced 100 mg of SiO 2 nanosphere was dissipated in 20 mL of water and ultrasonicated for 15 min.The colloidal SiO 2 nanospheres were later dispersed into a solution containing water (60 mL), ethanol (30 mL), and ammonia solution (0.55 mL) with cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) (150 mg).After the suspension was rotated for 0.5 h, 0.25 mL of TEOS was rapidly mixed, and later after 6 h, the resultant product was centrifuged and washed several times with ethanol and water and dried in an oven at 80 C for 6 h.The asprepared product was calcinated at 550 C in the air at a heating speed of 2 C min -1 for 6 h to eliminate CTAB to form the SiO 2 template. To prepare HC-C 3 N 4 , the as-prepared SiO 2 template was suspended in 60 mL of distilled water containing 10 g of dicyandiamide, mixed for overnight and then sonicated at 30 C for 2 h.Subsequently, the suspension was stirred at 60 C for the water to evaporate, and the resultant white solid was replaced into an alumina crucible and heated to 550 C under N 2 gas for 4 h with a heating rate of 5 C min -1 .The attained g-C 3 N 4 /SiO 2 product was soaked with 4 M NH 4 HF 2 for 24 h to eliminate silica template.The resultant product was then centrifuged and washed three times with distilled water and ethanol.The obtained HC-C 3 N 4 product was later dried in an oven at 80 C for 12 h. operation mode.context: The X-ray diffraction patterns of HC-C 3 N 4 and bulk C 3 N 4 samples are revealed in Fig. 1.Two typical characteristic diffractions at 2 13.0and27.1can be observed in the XRD patterns in both samples.The weak peak at 13.1is due to the in-plane architectural packing of continuous heptazine or striazine units that can be recorded to the (100) plane.The strong peak at 27.1signifies the interlayer loading of aromatic segments indexed to the (002) plane (JCPDS 087-1526).These two essential diffraction peaks illustrate that the asprepared samples are g-C 3 N 4 and very well matched with the earlier reports (Li et al. 2015d;Yang et al. 2015;Zhang et al. 2014).The reduction in (002) peak intensity of the HC-C 3 N 4 sample can be attributed to poor crystallization and the creation of large pores or hollow interior within the structure, which reduced the length of interlayer periodicity or atomic arrangements (Zhang et al. 2013;Talapaneni et al. 2012).The exterior arrangement of the HC-C 3 N 4 sample was further investigated by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM).The FESEM images show honeycomb morphology (Fig. 2a-d). The porous C 3 N 4 structure with a hollow interior replicates the precise nature of the SiO 2 templates after etching out as shown in Fig. 2a-d.The diameter of the interior hollows ranges ca.50-80 nm with irregular intervals in the C 3 N 4 framework on the surface of the sample.The porosity of the HC-C 3 N 4 texture framework is further supported by the TEM analysis Fig. 2e-f.The TEM characterization further shows the existence of interior hollow or pores introduced alongside with the considerable number of surface defects. The EDX elemental mapping images (Fig. 3) show a uniform allocation of both carbon (C) and nitrogen (N) as the only components within the HC-C 3 N 4 sample, without any other elements such as silica or oxygen.The elemental study shows that the HC-C 3 N 4 has a C/N molar ratio of 0.72, while the bulk C 3 N 4 shows 0.70.The respective stoichiometric C: N ratio is C 3.2 :N 4.4 and C 2.9 :N 4.1 for HC-C 3 N 4 and bulk C 3 N 4 , respectively.These results are nearby to the hypothetical value of 0.75 for ideal g-C 3 N 4 , suggesting some incomplete condensation which is normally examined in the preparation of g-C 3 N 4 (Kailasam et al. 2011;Li et al. 2012). The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the HC-C 3 N 4 sample was conducted to determine the thermal stability, decomposition behavior, and final carbon nitride content (i.e., purity).The HC-C 3 N 4 and bulk C 3 N 4 samples were warmed from ambient temperature to 900 C at a heating rate of 10 C min -1 under air, and the subsequent outcome is shown in Fig. 4. A complete weight loss takes place in both samples beyond 700 C after experiencing two stages of significant weight.The first stage occurred at 400 C with 6.7 and 5.5 wt losses for HC-C 3 N 4 and bulk C 3 N 4 , respectively, was caused by thermal removal of hydroxyl groups or bound water particles and other absorbed unstable contaminations on the facade of the samples.The second stage witnessed rapid and significant weight loss from 450 to 620 C corresponding to 91.7 wt loss for the HC-C 3 N 4 .The bulk-C 3 N 4 completely decomposes at 670 C, which corresponds to 94.1 wt.This reaction is generated from the decomposition of C-N bondrelated frameworks in the carbon nitride polymer and their sublimation into g-C 3 N 4 gaseous products.It can be observed from the TG curves that the decomposition behavior of the HC-C 3 N 4 occurred at a lower temperature relative to the bulk C 3 N 4 .This is due to the formation of hollows or pores within the C 3 N 4 matrix, which increases the mesoporosity and surface area of the HC-C 3 N 4 sample.These results make the HC-C 3 N 4 sample less heavy and lead to easily decomposed at lower temperatures. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) test was further conducted to disclose the microstructure of the HC-C 3 N 4 asprepared sample.There are similarities in the spectra characteristics of both HC-C 3 N 4 and bulk C 3 N 4 as-prepared samples as shown in Fig. 5.This signifies the excellent maintenance of both the heptazine (or s-triazine) band and trigonal C-N(-C)-C/bridging C-NH-C components in the samples.The sharp peak at around 811 cm -1 fits into the breathing mode of the heptazine or s-triazine band.The firm peaks at 1215-1640 cm -1 are ascribed to the elongation or bending vibration of the aromatic carbon and nitrogen heterocycles (i.e., C-N and/or CN bonds).Besides, the extensive characteristic band in a range of 3105-3700 cm -1 is attributed to the stretching vibrations of residual N-H bonds in the primary and secondary amines (NH or -NH 2 ) groups and adsorbed water molecules (Zheng et al. 2014;Kang et al. 2015).All these observations suggest that the HC-C 3 N 4 prepared is similar to the reference bulk C 3 N 4 with some NH or -NH 2 groups in the samples, an indication of incomplete condensation.It further shows that all the SiO 2 templates were etched out and the strong etching reagent (NH 4 HF 2 ) does not have any effect on the robust structure of the HC-C 3 N 4 synthesized. Figure 6 shows the N 2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and the corresponding pore size allocation curves of the asprepared samples.The entire samples exhibited type IV isotherms, suggesting the existence of mesopores inside the samples (Sing 1985).The profile of the hysteresis loops is of type H3, signifying the presence of slit-like mesopores owing to the accumulation of plate-like grains.Furthermore, it can be seen that the isotherms exhibited a high relative pressure range (approaching 1.0), signifying the arrangement of large mesopores and macropores.The pore size allocation curves ranged from 2 to 120 nm (inset in Fig. 6) further confirmed the mesoporosity of the samples.The HC-C 3 N 4 sample exhibited only the existence of large mesopores at a peak pore size of 42 nm and macropores at 75 nm.This was due to the successful creation of large interior hollows or cylindrical channels within the C 3 N 4 matrix of HC-C 3 N 4 samples, after the exclusion of the silica templates which is evidenced by the FESEM and TEM images.However, small mesopores (3.5-4.5 nm), huge mesopores, and macropores (42-75 nm) can be examined in the bulk sample.The BET values for the as-prepared samples are shown in Table 1.It can be seen that the HC-C 3 N 4 sample has a significantly higher surface area and pore volume (2.5 times higher) than the bulk C 3 N 4 .This can be ascribed to the creation of a huge amount of macropores within the C 3 N 4 matrix.This results would lead to effective surface absorption of reactants and faster photogenerated carrier separation and thus enhancement in photocatalytic activity.The reduction in the BET values in the HC-C 3 N 4 /Ni(OH) 2 sample can be attributed to the evidence of the Ni(OH) 2 cocatalyst which may be ingrained in the C 3 N 4 pores and thus decreasing the BET surface area and pore volume. The chemical distribution and elemental status of HC-C 3 N 4 and bulk C 3 N 4 were distinguished by XPS analysis, and the outcome is illustrated in Fig. 7a.The survey spectra of both samples show only C, N, and O elements.There was no signal detection of silicon species which confirms the successful removal of the SiO 2 templates used in the preparation of the HC-C 3 N 4 .However, the presence of the O1s peak could be attributed to exterior preoccupied water molecules as definite by the FT-IR results (Fig. 5). Figure 7b shows that C1s peak deconvoluted into three peaks.The peak at 286.4 and 288.0 eV binding energies are attributed to sp 2 C-C bonds and sp 2 -hybridized carbon in nitrogen-incorporated aromatic ring (N-CN), respectively.However, the peak at binding energy (284.exterior extrinsic carbon, derived from the sample and the XPS instrument itself (Yang et al. 2015;Zheng et al. 2014).The high-resolution XPS spectra of N 1s were indexed into four peaks at binding energies 398.4,399.0, 400.3, and 404.2 eV, respectively, as shown in Fig. 7c.The highest peak at 398.4 eV binding energies is ascribed to sp 2 -hybridized aromatic nitrogen bonding in the triazine rings with two carbon atoms (C-NC).The peak at 400.3 eV correlates to the tertiary nitrogen N-(C)3 groups.Both peaks jointly with sp 2hybridized carbon (N-CN, at 288.0 eV) conform to heptazine heterocyclic ring units which are the essential building substructure for g-C 3 N 4 .The weak peak at 400.3 eV can be allocated to N-H bonds which indicate the presence of amino functional groups due to the deficient concentration of poly (tri-s-triazine) structures (Gu et al. 2015;Qin et al. 2015).The weakest peak at binding energy (404.2eV) can be credited to -excitations or positive charge localization in the heterocycles (Li et al. 2015a, b, c, d;Yu et al. 2014a, b).
